title.narrative: Améliorer la sécurité alimentaire et nutritionnelle au Nord Bénin à travers une meilleure gouvernance foncière

description.narrative:
Depuis le début de la décentralisation, les Universités nationales en général du Bénin et l’UP en particulier est sollicitée de façon croissante par nombre de parties prenantes alarmées par l’insécurité alimentaire et la pression foncière. Face à cette demande, l’initiative sécurité foncière et sécurité alimentaire et nutritionnelle (SF-SAN) du présent projet TMT permettra de répondre à long termes aux besoins actuels des populations.
Les difficultés de disponibilité et d’accès aux intrants agricoles et au foncier constituent l’une des principales raisons qui expliqueraient l’insécurité alimentaire au Benin. L’accès au foncier est déterminé par plusieurs facteurs socio-économiques d’où l’intérêt du projet TMT pour la gouvernance foncière comme un chemin vers une meilleure sécurité alimentaire et nutritionnelle au Nord Benin.
Dans les pays comme le Benin où l’agriculture demeure la principale source de moyens d’existence et de subsistance pour les populations (principalement celles rurales), l’accès à la terre est un élément fondamental. Des droits de propriétés sécurisés permettent ou favorisent des investissements conséquents voire l’utilisation de techniques de productions durables telles que les pratiques de gestion et conservation de la fertilité des sols.
Dans le Nord du Benin, les phénomènes tels que le non accès aux terres agricoles, l’amenuisement des terres du fait de la pression démographique, les conflits pastoraux, conduisent les jeunes ruraux à traverser les frontières pour se retrouver pris aux pièges des migrations.

Les objectifs seront de renforcer les capacités du système éducatif de l‘université de Parakou (UP) pour une offre de services SF-SAN de qualité et ceci à travers une prise en compte des questions de SF-SAN. Ce faisant, le projet devrait permettra de transformer l’UP en un centre de référence en matière d’analyse des systèmes SF-SAN et de développement de politiques et stratégies pour répondre aux questions SF-SAN.

participating-org.narrative: Institut National de l'Eau, Université Abomey-Calavi, Bénin

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

In this section (maximum 1000 words), please provide a global overview of the project progress **per output**. To what extent have they been achieved? Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

title.narrative: B. Enhanced knowledge and skills of individuals and organisations (in partner countries and in the NL) in line with country/regional specific labour market needs & aiming at inclusiveness
B.I.1. Number of scholarship holders / TMT participants that have successfully completed course/training (male / female / minorities)
B.O.1. Number of organisations strengthened by individual and/or group training
B.I.6. Number of stimulating measures/extra facilities aimed at preparation, supervision and aftercare of female candidates
B.I.4. % of scholarships awarded to women
B.O.2. % of alumni / TMT participants who have applied the acquired knowledge and skills within their working environment
B.I.2. % scholarship holder's /TMT participants / alumni satisfaction
B.I.8. % alumni / TMT participants who state that they have acquired new knowledge and skills; e.g. problem solving, effective communication
B.I.10. Changes in personal, academic and professional attitudes and attributes through training and education programmes
B.I.11. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the workplace
